title: Quiz 8: Comprehensive Anatomy Mega Review
description: An advanced integration quiz covering high-yield concepts from the abdomen, pelvis, limbs, head, neck, and nervous system.

questions.question: A patient presents with a mid-shaft fracture of the humerus. Which nerve is most at risk of injury, and what clinical sign would be observed?

options.text: Axillary nerve; Loss of shoulder abduction

questions.explanation: The radial nerve runs in the spiral groove of the humerus and is susceptible to injury in mid-shaft fractures. Damage leads to paralysis of the extensors of the wrist and fingers, resulting in 'wrist drop'.
questions.hint: Think about the nerve that travels in the spiral groove.

questions.question: Regarding the inguinal canal and hernias, which of the following statements are CORRECT? (Select all that apply)

options.text: An indirect inguinal hernia passes lateral to the inferior epigastric vessels
A direct inguinal hernia passes medial to the inferior epigastric vessels
The deep inguinal ring is a defect in the external oblique aponeurosis
The conjoint tendon forms the medial part of the posterior wall
Indirect hernias are controlled by pressure over the superficial ring

questions.explanation: Indirect hernias enter the deep ring lateral to the inferior epigastric artery. Direct hernias push through the posterior wall (Hesselbach's triangle) medial to the artery. The deep ring is in the transversalis fascia, not the external oblique (which contains the superficial ring).
questions.hint: Consider the anatomical relationship to the inferior epigastric artery.

questions.question: Match the cranial nerve with its specific function or characteristic:

pairs.right: Has a long intracranial course; first affected by raised ICP
Carries taste from anterior 2/3 of tongue

questions.explanation: CN III opens the eye. CN IV supplies the 'muscle with the pulley'. CN VI abducts the eye and is vulnerable to pressure. CN VII supplies facial muscles and taste (via chorda tympani).
questions.hint: Recall the specific muscle innervations and sensory distributions.

questions.question: Trace the path of a drop of urine from the renal papilla to the bladder:
questions.explanation: Urine flows from the renal papilla -> minor calyx -> major calyx -> renal pelvis -> ureter -> bladder.
questions.hint: Think about the collecting system from small to large structures.

questions.question: Review the table below regarding the autonomic nervous system. Which row correctly identifies the characteristics of the Sympathetic division?

richContent.content:
RowOutflowPreganglionic FibersGanglia Location
ACraniosacralLongNear/In Viscera
BThoracolumbarShortParavertebral Chain
CThoracolumbarLongNear Viscera

questions.explanation: The Sympathetic system has a Thoracolumbar outflow (T1-L2), relatively short preganglionic fibers, and synapses primarily in the sympathetic trunk (paravertebral) ganglia close to the spine.
questions.hint: Sympathetic is 'fight or flight' originating from the thoracic and lumbar cord.

questions.question: The right lung has three lobes and its main bronchus is wider, shorter, and more vertical than the left.
questions.explanation: The right lung has three lobes (superior, middle, inferior). The right main bronchus is indeed wider, shorter, and more vertical, making it the most common site for inhaled foreign bodies.
questions.hint: Consider why aspiration pneumonia is more common on the right side.

questions.question: Which of the following structures pass through the diaphragm at the level of T10? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Diaphragm openings: T8 = IVC; T10 = Oesophagus + Vagal trunks; T12 = Aorta + Thoracic duct + Azygos vein.
questions.hint: Remember the mnemonic 'Voice (8), Eggs (10), At (12)'.

questions.question: The portal vein is formed behind the neck of the pancreas by the union of the ___BLANK___ vein and the ___BLANK___ vein.
questions.explanation: The portal vein is formed by the confluence of the superior mesenteric vein and the splenic vein behind the pancreatic neck.
questions.hint: One vein drains the midgut, the other drains the spleen.

questions.question: A patient presents with 'winging of the scapula'. Which nerve is damaged and which muscle is paralyzed?
questions.explanation: Damage to the long thoracic nerve (C5, 6, 7) paralyzes the serratus anterior muscle. This muscle holds the scapula against the chest wall; without it, the medial border protrudes (wings).
questions.hint: The nerve supplies the muscle that protracts the scapula ('boxer's muscle').

questions.question: Which of the following form the 'Rotator Cuff' of the shoulder? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: The rotator cuff consists of Supraspinatus, Infraspinatus, Teres Minor, and Subscapularis (SITS). Teres Major is NOT part of the cuff.
questions.hint: Remember the acronym SITS.

questions.question: What is the name of the fibrous cord that connects the apex of the bladder to the umbilicus (a remnant of the urachus)?
questions.explanation: The apex of the bladder is connected to the umbilicus by the median umbilical ligament, which is the obliterated remnant of the embryonic urachus.
questions.hint: It is found in the midline of the anterior abdominal wall.

questions.question: A patient has a lesion of the femoral nerve. Which of the following deficits would be expected?

options.text: Loss of sensation on the lateral thigh

questions.explanation: The femoral nerve supplies the quadriceps femoris, which extends the knee. Adduction is obturator nerve; knee flexion is sciatic nerve; lateral thigh sensation is the lateral cutaneous nerve of the thigh.
questions.hint: The femoral nerve supplies the anterior compartment of the thigh.

questions.question: Match the Porto-Systemic Anastomosis site with the veins involved:
questions.explanation: These anastomoses allow blood to bypass the liver in portal hypertension. Esophageal varices, hemorrhoids, and caput medusae are clinical signs.
questions.hint: Match the anatomical location to the specific venous tributaries.

questions.question: Which structure passes THROUGH the carpal tunnel?
questions.explanation: The carpal tunnel contains the Median nerve and 9 flexor tendons (FDS, FDP, FPL). The ulnar nerve passes superficial to the flexor retinaculum. Palmaris longus is also superficial.
questions.hint: Compression of this nerve causes Carpal Tunnel Syndrome.

questions.question: Arrange the layers of the scalp from superficial to deep:
questions.explanation: SCALP: Skin, Connective tissue, Aponeurosis, Loose connective tissue, Pericranium.
questions.hint: Use the mnemonic SCALP.

questions.question: What is the primary action of the Tibialis Posterior muscle?
questions.explanation: Tibialis Posterior is a deep muscle of the posterior calf. It plantarflexes and inverts the foot. Tibialis Anterior dorsiflexes and inverts.
questions.hint: It pulls the foot down and inwards.

questions.question: Which of the following are contents of the Carotid Sheath? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: The carotid sheath contains the Common/Internal Carotid arteries, Internal Jugular Vein, and Vagus Nerve. The Sympathetic trunk is posterior to the sheath.
questions.hint: Think IJV, Carotid, and CN X.

questions.question: A patient has a 'surgical neck' fracture of the humerus. Which artery is most at risk?
questions.explanation: The posterior circumflex humeral artery and the axillary nerve wind around the surgical neck of the humerus and are at risk in fractures here.
questions.hint: It circumflexes the humerus at the fracture site.

questions.question: The right renal artery passes posterior to the inferior vena cava.
questions.explanation: Because the aorta is to the left of the midline and the IVC is to the right, the right renal artery must pass BEHIND the IVC to reach the right kidney.
questions.hint: Visualise the positions of the Aorta (left) and IVC (right).

questions.question: The ___BLANK___ nerve supplies the muscles of facial expression, while the ___BLANK___ nerve supplies the muscles of mastication.
questions.explanation: Muscles of facial expression are supplied by the Facial nerve (CN VII). Muscles of mastication are supplied by the Mandibular division of the Trigeminal nerve (CN V3).
questions.hint: CN VII vs CN V.

questions.question: Match the ligament to the joint it stabilizes:
questions.explanation: Cruciates (ACL/PCL) stabilize the knee. Annular holds the radius. Iliofemoral (Bigelow) stabilizes the hip. Glenohumeral stabilizes the shoulder.
questions.hint: Connect the name of the ligament to the bones involved.

questions.question: Which of the following defines McBurney's point?

options.text: Midpoint between umbilicus and pubic symphysis
1/3 of the way from ASIS to umbilicus
2/3 of the way from ASIS to umbilicus
The tip of the 9th costal cartilage

questions.explanation: McBurney's point lies one-third of the way along a line joining the anterior superior iliac spine (ASIS) and the umbilicus. It marks the base of the appendix.
questions.hint: It is closer to the hip than the navel.

questions.question: Which of the following are clinical signs of Horner's Syndrome? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Horner's syndrome results from loss of sympathetic supply. Signs are Ptosis, Miosis, Anhidrosis (and Enophthalmos, not Exophthalmos).
questions.hint: Think about what happens when 'fight or flight' is lost in the face.

questions.question: A fracture of the fibular neck typically damages which nerve, and results in which condition?
questions.explanation: The common peroneal nerve winds superficially around the neck of the fibula. Damage paralyzes the dorsiflexors (anterior compartment), causing foot drop.
questions.hint: The nerve is very subcutaneous at the lateral side of the knee.

questions.question: The trachea bifurcates into the right and left main bronchi at the level of the manubriosternal joint. What is the anatomical name for this joint level?
questions.explanation: The Angle of Louis (Sternal Angle) is at the T4/T5 vertebral level and marks the bifurcation of the trachea.
questions.hint: It is a palpable ridge on the sternum.

questions.question: Which artery is the principal blood supply to the perineum?
questions.explanation: The internal pudendal artery (branch of internal iliac) exits the pelvis, enters the gluteal region, and re-enters the perineum via the lesser sciatic foramen to supply it.
questions.hint: It runs in Alcock's canal.

questions.question: The spleen lies directly deep to the 9th, 10th, and 11th ribs on the right side.
questions.explanation: FALSE. The spleen lies under the 9th, 10th, and 11th ribs on the LEFT side.
questions.hint: Check the laterality (Left vs Right).

questions.question: Which of the following structures pass through the Superior Orbital Fissure? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: CN III, IV, VI, and the Ophthalmic division of V (V1) pass through the superior orbital fissure, along with ophthalmic veins. The Optic nerve passes through the Optic Canal.
questions.hint: Nerves that move the eye pass here; the nerve for vision does not.

questions.question: Order the branches of the aortic arch from Right to Left:
questions.explanation: The order is Brachiocephalic, Left Common Carotid, Left Subclavian (BCS).
questions.hint: ABC - Aorta, Brachiocephalic, Carotid, Subclavian.

questions.question: Read the text below regarding the thyroid gland. What is the clinical significance of the recurrent laryngeal nerve's relation to the inferior thyroid artery?

richContent.content: The inferior thyroid artery crosses the vertebral artery to reach the thyroid gland. It has a variable relation to the recurrent laryngeal nerve, lying in front of or behind it, or branching around it.

options.text: Ligation of the artery can inadvertently damage the nerve, causing hoarseness
The nerve supplies blood to the artery
Damage to the nerve causes loss of sensation to the skin of the neck
The artery must always be ligated lateral to the nerve

questions.explanation: During thyroidectomy, ligation of the inferior thyroid artery poses a risk to the recurrent laryngeal nerve due to their close and variable proximity. Damage leads to vocal cord paralysis and hoarseness.
questions.hint: Think about the function of the recurrent laryngeal nerve.
